image.altText: A young man with a beard.

items.synopsis: A major police operation is underway in Kellerberrin, with people being asked to stay indoors after a person was shot dead at a grain silo.

title.children: Active shooter in camouflage gear on loose, police manhunt underway after man shot dead at WA grain silo

image.altText: A home under construction with timber frame and one external brick wall.

items.synopsis: WA home builder BGC is set to be hit with a massive class action as potentially thousands of disgruntled home owners seek compensation after waiting years for their homes to be built.

title.children: Huge class action set to be launched against Perth builder that left customers waiting years for new homes

image.altText: A smiling young man in a racing driver's jumpsuit holds a trophy and raises his finger in triumph.

items.synopsis: Formula 500 driver Luke Nardini has been charged with manslaughter following a crash that occurred while he was allegedly driving on the wrong side of a US highway. His mother says her son is deeply saddened by the "terrible" incident.

title.children: Community devastated as Australian racing driver charged over deadly crash in California

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe is giving his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week as he speaks on the central bank's actions during the pandemic and interest rates. Follow live.

title.children: Lowe admits RBA 'did too much' when it came to interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And with that, the speech by the outgoing RBA governor has come to an end, as has the formalities that were happening at the end. It was a pretty wide-ranging speech — after all, he has spent the past seven years in the job, and has a career spanning decades at the central bank. To summarise it, in case you're just joining us: Philip Lowe conceded some mistakes in the top job, claimed some major successes, and also warned of the changing nature of inflation. If you were watching or listening, what did you make of it? What is your reaction to his admission that the RBA 'did too much'? Let me know your thoughts by hitting the blue button at the top of the blog, and I'll share some of them soon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: That's it for Philip Lowe's final speech as RBA governor

children.content: And with that, the speech by the outgoing RBA governor has come to an end, as has the formalities that were happening at the end.
It was a pretty wide-ranging speech — after all, he has spent the past seven years in the job, and has a career spanning decades at the central bank.
To summarise it, in case you're just joining us: Philip Lowe conceded some mistakes in the top job, claimed some major successes, and also warned of the changing nature of inflation.
If you were watching or listening, what did you make of it? What is your reaction to his admission that the RBA 'did too much'?
Let me know your thoughts by hitting the blue button at the top of the blog, and I'll share some of them soon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Bill Evans from Westpac gets the final question, who repeats a comment made by Alan Greenspan, a former chair of the US Federal Reserve. Greenspan said "I'll tell you when I get there" when he was asked what the neutral interest rate was. Evans asked for Lowe's take on the question — here's how he replied: "I'm going to disappoint you," he begins. "I can never understand Greenspan's perspective here. "We're making really important decisions on behalf of the country that can be unpopular, they affect the distribution of income, so they're really important decisions. "And given that, we need, I think, we need to be as accountable as we can and explain our decisions as clearly as we can. "And the reasons why we taking those decisions and the trade offs we're managing. 
I cannot see how can help the situation by being unclear. "At various points in time, I've struggled to be as clear as I wanted to be, but I've always sought to explain things as clearly as possible. "Australian should expect us to take important decisions, we affect all your lives, and you have a right to know why we take those decisions and how we manage them. "In terms of the neutral interest rate, I'm going to leave that to my successor."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The final question to Lowe: What is the neutral interest rate?

children.content: Bill Evans from Westpac gets the final question, who repeats a comment made by Alan Greenspan, a former chair of the US Federal Reserve.
Greenspan said "I'll tell you when I get there" when he was asked what the neutral interest rate was.
Evans asked for Lowe's take on the question — here's how he replied:
"I'm going to disappoint you," he begins.
"I can never understand Greenspan's perspective here.
"We're making really important decisions on behalf of the country that can be unpopular, they affect the distribution of income, so they're really important decisions.
"And given that, we need, I think, we need to be as accountable as we can and explain our decisions as clearly as we can.

"And the reasons why we taking those decisions and the trade offs we're managing. 
I cannot see how can help the situation by being unclear.
"At various points in time, I've struggled to be as clear as I wanted to be, but I've always sought to explain things as clearly as possible.
"Australian should expect us to take important decisions, we affect all your lives, and you have a right to know why we take those decisions and how we manage them.
"In terms of the neutral interest rate, I'm going to leave that to my successor."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lowe is asked what was a bigger challenge during his term — low inflation and near zero interest rates or high inflation? Here's how he replied: "By far the biggest challenge I have faced was the pandemic," he says. "You know, as I said in my prepared remarks, it was an incredibly scary time. "The economy, we risked 15% unemployment, or being told that contraction could last for years, the vaccine wasn't going to be developed and we reduced interest rates to zero, we thought probably that is not enough. "We coordinated very effectively with the government, and that helped, and we had to come up with these innovative policy instruments, so that was by far the most challenging time. "Raising interest rates, while it makes you unpopular, it is the right thing to do, and the job of the central bank and the central bank [and] governor is to be unpopular at certain points in time and do the right thing for the country. "That's what we did."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What was more challenging, low inflation and interest rates, or high inflation?

children.content: Lowe is asked what was a bigger challenge during his term — low inflation and near zero interest rates or high inflation?
Here's how he replied:
"By far the biggest challenge I have faced was the pandemic," he says.
"You know, as I said in my prepared remarks, it was an incredibly scary time.

"The economy, we risked 15% unemployment, or being told that contraction could last for years, the vaccine wasn't going to be developed and we reduced interest rates to zero, we thought probably that is not enough.
"We coordinated very effectively with the government, and that helped, and we had to come up with these innovative policy instruments, so that was by far the most challenging time.

"Raising interest rates, while it makes you unpopular, it is the right thing to do, and the job of the central bank and the central bank [and] governor is to be unpopular at certain points in time and do the right thing for the country.
"That's what we did."

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

image.altText: A luxury cruise on the ocean ship beneath a clear sky.

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

image.altText: water collected in the basin of marri tree reflecting the sky and tree branches

title.children: How ancient horticulture helped First Nations people create southern WA's 'water trees'

image.altText: A woman stands at a table outside surrounded by buckets of pink and white Geraldton Wax flowers.

items.synopsis: Planting flowers in the middle of a drought doesn't seem like the obvious choice to diversify but this family has said goodbye to sheep and hello to hundreds of Geraldton wax plants.

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

image.altText: A woman crouching looking up at a furry animal and patting it as its held by another person.

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing rainfall anomaly patterns, mostly red to indicate dryness. A date indicates August 2023

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: A plane flying in a blue sky.

items.synopsis: It costs $150,000 to become a pilot, but juniors would be "lucky" to earn $35,000 in their first year, according to the Australian and International Pilots Association.

image.altText: A sweaty Daniil Medvedev wraps a towel around his head with a look of relief on his face.

image.altText: Jack Robinson walking with his surfboard under his arm after competing

image.altText: A group of men wearing suits

items.synopsis: Police allege the 61-year-old concealed a serious indictable offence after the incident on Friday night, where two people were killed in Sydney's south-west.

image.altText: three men at sea.

items.synopsis: Australian Border Force officers have greeted three sailors who had to be rescued from a sinking catamaran in the Coral Sea.

image.altText: a small shark out of water

image.altText: Person holds woman who is emotional behind them is debris of homes

items.synopsis: Large swathes of the US, Europe and Asia are battling concurrent natural disasters, leaving hundreds dead and thousands displaced. Here's the latest from across the world.

image.altText: A man in a dark corner putting his hands on a red brick wall and his feet on the opposite white wall floating above ground

image.altText: a baby maugean skate in front of a light, looks translucent and glows red
